definition: to showcase one's (unique) talents/to display one's (individual) prowess
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
surname Zhan
to spread out/to open up/to exhibit/to put into effect/to postpone/to prolong/exhibition
body/life/oneself/personally/one's morality and conduct/the main part of a structure or body/pregnant/classifier for sets of clothes: suit, twinset/Kangxi radical 158
hand/(formal) to hold/person engaged in certain types of work/person skilled in certain types of work/personal(ly)/convenient/classifier for skill/CL:雙|双[shuang1],隻|只[zhi1]

sentences.english: It also includes many team cooperations.
sentences.chinese: 它又是一場一展身手的團隊協作。

sentences.english: He constantly feels he has to prove himself to others.
sentences.chinese: 他時常覺得自己必須向人一展身手。

sentences.english: Check out the free version if you want to have a go.
sentences.chinese: 退房自由的版本，如果你想一展身手。

sentences.english: They foster social skills and are opportunities for play and exercise.
sentences.chinese: 在活動中培養了社交技巧並且有機會一展身手。

sentences.english: They are just waiting now for the chance to play well in the next match.
sentences.chinese: 他們只是等待下場比賽的機會一展身手。

sentences.english: This is where the Open Closed Principle comes into play.
sentences.chinese: 這就是開閉原則一展身手的地方了。

sentences.english: According to Bell, Yahoo is looking forward to seeing what developers will do with this data.
sentences.chinese: 貝爾說，雅虎很期待開發者能利用這些數據一展身手。

sentences.english: Roy Hodgson does not expect to be a busy man when the transfer window opens next month.
sentences.chinese: 霍大爺並不打算在冬季轉會中一展身手。

sentences.english: OK let's have a go at drawing something like this open book.
sentences.chinese: 行讓我們一展身手的繪圖本打開的書一樣的東西。

definition: (idiom) fully displaying one's capabilities
fig. to rub one's fists and wipe one's palms (idiom)/to roll up one's sleeves for battle/eager to get into action or start on a task
variant of 摩拳擦掌[mo1 quan2 ca1 zhang3]
to be eager to give sth a try (idiom)
to display one's remarkable skill or prowess/to give full play to one's brilliant abilities
to accomplish much/to have good prospects/to have a promising future
Chinese boxing/fist and feet/punching and kicking
to look/to have a glimpse at/to observe (sth's splendor)
to feast one's eyes
to shine (of talents, skills, accomplishment)/to demonstrate extraordinary talent or skill
to give a small demonstration of one's impressive skills (idiom)
first sign of budding talent/to display one's ability for the first time
ample scope for abilities/favorable position for the use of one's skills (idiom)
like a fish back in water (idiom); glad to be back in one's proper surroundings
to have a show-down/to fight for mastery/to compete for a championship
to stand out among one's peers (idiom)/to excel
